page_analysis.text_content:
Accessory structure daylight plane (sides & rear)

Fig 25 Front elevation showing accessory-structure daylight plane at the side of the lot

Note: For accessory buildings near the rear & side lot lines, a hipped gable roof is often the best solution for complying with the accessory-structure daylight plane.

Fig 26 Side elevation showing accessory-structure daylight plane at the rear of the lot

Side

32

visual_elements.description: Front elevation diagram showing an accessory structure (garage-like building) with measurements indicating '3' at the top, '8' from average grade to roof peak, '24' for max height of building, and 'Side lot line' marked on both sides. Shows daylight plane with dashed lines extending from the structure.

Side elevation diagram showing an accessory structure from the side view with measurements indicating '3' at the top, '8' from average grade to roof, '24' for max height of building, and 'Rear lot line' marked at the bottom. Shows daylight plane with dashed lines.
Small square diagram in bottom right showing directional arrows pointing to 'Front', 'Rear', and 'Side' with diagonal line across the square labeled 'Side'.

technical_specifications.parameter: Distance from structure to daylight plane origin
Height from average grade to roof peak

additional_notes: Page number 32 appears at bottom left
Gray header bar spans width of page under main heading
Diagrams show cross-sectional views of accessory structures with daylight plane requirements
Dashed lines in diagrams represent daylight plane angles
cross_references: Fig 25 - Front elevation showing accessory-structure daylight plane at the side of the lot
Fig 26 - Side elevation showing accessory-structure daylight plane at the rear of the lot
